questions.clue: These colossal stone statues on Easter Island were created by the Rapa Nui people.
An ancient city in Jordan, famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system, rediscovered by the Western world in 1812.
The construction methods of these ancient South American structures in Peru remain a mystery, as the stones fit together so precisely.
This ancient mathematical artifact found in the South of England may have been used to predict eclipses and solstices.
The undeciphered script found on clay tablets from the Indus Valley Civilization, existing from 3300 to 1300 BCE, is known as this.
This English chemist is known for her pioneering research on the structure of DNA.
She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and she won it twice, in Physics and Chemistry.
This astrophysicist helped discover pulsars, leading to a Nobel Prize awarded to her supervisor.
As a NASA mathematician, she calculated orbital mechanics that were crucial for the success of the first U.S. crewed spaceflights.
She became the first female minister of Research and Science in Italy and has a major element named after her.
This Austrian composer is famous for his symphonies, notably No. 5 and No. 9.
This Russian composer is known for ballets like 'The Nutcracker' and 'Swan Lake'.
Though Finnish, this composer is famous for 'Finlandia' and 'The Swan of Tuonela'.
This Hungarian composer, who brought Hungarian folk music to the classical stage, composed 'Romanian Folk Dances'.
This Brazilian composer of 'Bachianas Brasileiras' integrated Brazilian folk and popular music with classical forms.
This world capital is home to the Eiffel Tower, an iron tower built for the 1889 World's Fair.
The Colosseum, an ancient amphitheater, can be found in this European capital city.
In this city, you can visit the iconic Blue Mosque, known for its blue tiles, built during the early 17th century.
The Petronas Towers, once the world's tallest buildings, are a defining feature of this Malaysian capital.
This capital city features the Alhambra, a UNESCO World Heritage site and a stunning example of Moorish architecture.
This type of panel, often installed on rooftops, converts sunlight into electricity.
These large turbines harness wind energy to produce electricity and are commonly found in fields or offshore.
Cars that use this type of powertrain combine a gasoline engine with an electric motor to improve fuel efficiency.
This process captures carbon dioxide emissions from sources like power plants and stores it underground to prevent its release into the atmosphere.
This sustainable building certification system, originating in the U.S., rates the environmental performance of structures and is known by the acronym LEED.
questions.answer: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design

final.clue: This 1608 play was believed to be inspired by the sinking of the Sea Venture, a ship wrecked on Bermuda during its 1609 voyage to this colony.
